document wearing schedule -Elbow flexion contracture may cause skin breakdown in the antecubital space(6) -Clenched-fist  deformity: may cause palmar skin breakdown and hygiene problems, including recurrent infections of the fingernail beds(6) -Shoulder contracture: can cause hygiene problems in the axilla(6) -Note redness, ability to blanch, actual breakdown in skin, and size/stage any wounds and notify physician -Inspect for any bruising or injury that may indicate falls or collisions with furniture and other objects. Also inspect paretic hand and foot for neglect-related  injuries, such as getting hand caught in wheelchair spokes or not placing foot on wheelchair foot rest •Perception:  No single gold-standard  assessment exists(30) –Many assessments measure function impairment by observing ability to perform paper-and-pencil  tasks. Other assessments measure limitations in activity or participation by observing ability to perform ADLs. Virtual-reality computer-based  assessments have more recently been developed(30) –Researchers in the United States found that detection of neglect may depend on the assessment administered(30) -Their data supports the use of functional assessments and virtual-  reality assessments over the use of paper-and-pencil–based  assessments because they were better at detecting neglect –Obtain results of any neuropsychological tests where available -Results of cognitive testing, vision testing, and testing for perceptual deficits including but not limited to neglect (e.g., agnosia) may be available –A large number of simple and rapid tests have been developed for the assessment of neglect. A combination of several tests is usually recommended because of the variability in the tests that patients fail, probably reflecting differences in the nature of the underlying deficits -See section Special tests specific to diagnosis , below, for a list of perception tests that may be used –When a client is medically stable or has a positive screen for the presence of unilateral neglect, an in-depth  evaluation should be done to identify the specific deficits that require intervention –The Catherine Bergego Scale (CBS) is a perception tool that requires direct observation of post-stroke  patients in everyday activities(38)    -Ten everyday activities: dressing, grooming, eating, mouth cleaning, personal belongings, safe mobility, gaze orientation, auditory attention, spatial orientation, and knowledge of left limbs are evaluated -This scale can also be administered as a questionnaire to assess how the patient self-evaluates  his/her neglect during ADLs using the same scoring system -The CBS captures the heterogeneity of spatial neglect by examining functional performance in personal, peripersonal, and extrapersonal space, as well as performance in perceptual, mental imagery, and motor domains. Thus it is more sensitive than paper-and-pencil  tests(23) –The Kessler Foundation Neglect Assessment Process (KF-NAP)  is an assessment tool based on the CBS(23) -The KF-NAP  provides detailed administration instructions and a scoring chart for the 10 original categories of behavior -The KF-NAP  has been shown to uniquely quantify symptoms of spatial neglect by measuring functional difficulties that are not captured by the FIM or Barthel Index –Tests of neglect might also include asking patients to mime ADL activities, such as combing their hair, shaving, or makingup their face –Inclusion of tests that maintain the complexity of everyday tasks and environments is recommended(31) •Posture –Assess static and dynamic posture in sitting and standing, looking at symmetry(4) –Unilateral neglect interferes with a patient’s ability to maintain static posture -Patients have difficulty maintaining symmetrical posture. They may lean toward the ipsilesional side -Unaware their posture isn’t upright even if leaning heavily onto someone or something -Often unaware they are falling –Postural Assessment Scale for Stroke Patients (PASS)(4) may be used to assess posture –Patients who use wheelchairs tend to slump towards the ipsilesional side of their chair and direct their gaze towards ipsilesional space •Range of motion: Assess active and passive ROM, as well as flexibility throughout(4) •Reflex testing: Assess deep tendon reflexes bilaterally and compare. Assess for primitive reflexes, as well as clonus and Babinski as indicated •Self-care/activities  of daily living (objective testing) : Assess the effect of neglect on self-care  and functional tasks using standardized assessments, such as Rivermead Mobility Index or Barthel Index –The effects of unilateral neglect extend beyond the basic skills for self-care (e.g., bathing, dressing, feeding) to instrumental activities of daily living (IADLs) •Sensory testing:  Light touch, kinesthesia, two-point  discrimination, proprioception, texture recognition, deep sensation(4) –Assessment of kinesthetic deficits is important. In a study involving 158 individuals an average of 18 days post stroke, researchers in the United States found that the presence of visuospatial neglect is highly predictive of the presence of kinesthetic deficits; however, the presence of kinesthetic deficits does not necessarily indicate the presence of visuospatial neglect(24) -Participants with neglect had impaired kinesthesia 100% of the time, whereas only 59% of participants without neglect had impaired kinesthesia •Special tests specific to diagnosis: There are more than 60 measures that assess neglect.(30)Currently there are no anatomical location body part affected: Brain; upper and/or lower limb contralateral to the brain lesion, trunk
description: Stroke is an infarction or hemorrhage in the brain that results in sudden onset of focal neurologic deficit(1) –An estimated 7.2 million persons in the United States ≥ 20 years of age have had a stroke(15) –About 795,000 persons experience a new or recurrent stroke each year, and stroke is the leading cause of serious, long-term  disability in the United States(15)
Unilateral neglect is a disabling feature of stroke, defined as the failure to report, respond, or orient to stimuli presented contralateral to the brain lesion(37)

Estimates of the frequency of neglect vary and depend on the tests and criteria used –Although unilateral neglect can occur after damage to either hemisphere, left neglect due to right hemisphere damage is much more common, longer lasting, and more severe than right neglect due to left hemisphere damage –In the acute phase, prevalence of neglect is reported to be around 50% in right brain lesions(37)

Unilateral neglect may be subdivided into three major categories of attentional deficits:(37) –Memory and representational deficits – lack of awareness of the contralesional half of a mental representation or visualization of a task or environment –Action-intentional  disorders (motor neglect) – lack of spontaneous movement in the contralesional space that is not due to a deficit of the motor pathway –Inattention (sensory neglect) – lack of awareness of sensory stimuli on the contralesional side of the body or space

Unilateral neglect may also be subdivided by the distribution of the abnormal behavior, into personal or spatial neglect –Personal neglect: an inability to attend to one side of one’s body(27,37) -Patients may not recognize that parts of their bodies belong to them (called “asomatognosia”)(27) –Spatial neglect: failure to acknowledge stimuli on the contralesional side of space(37) -Peripersonal (also called “near extrapersonal”) spatial neglect: the inability to attend to the space within reaching distance(3) -Extrapersonal (also called “far extrapersonal”) spatial neglect: the inability to attend to the space beyond reaching distance(3)

This review focuses on the assessment and management of unilateral neglect during stroke rehabilitation. reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no special agencies have been identified for stroke. Treatment approaches that have been identified as investigational or experimental (e.g., constraint-induced  movement therapy [CIMT]) are frequently not covered or require specified criteria to be met

Presentation/signs and symptoms –Early warning signs of stroke  (4) -Sudden numbness or weakness of the face, arm, or leg, typically unilateral -Sudden confusion, difficulty speaking or understanding speech -Sudden difficulty seeing in one or both eyes -Sudden difficulty walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or coordination -Sudden, severe headache -Individuals also may experience sudden nausea, fever, vomiting, or brief loss of consciousness –Potential signs and symptoms following stroke, both acute and chronic -Visual system impact -Visual changes, including homonymous hemianopsia(4) -Diplopia(5) -Nystagmus(5) -Horner’s syndrome(5) -Neuromusculoskeletal system impact -Unilateral paresis, abnormal muscle tone and motor control, and poor coordination -Weakness is seen in 80–90%  of all persons with stroke(4) -Altered motor programming: difficulty planning and executing purposeful movements(4) -Alterations in tone – initially flaccid paralysis occurs, followed by the development of spasticity, hyperreflexia, and mass patterns of movement(4) -Upper extremity synergy patterns -Flexor: scapular retraction/elevation or hyperextension, shoulder abduction, external rotation, elbow flexion, forearm supination, wrist and finger flexion -Extensor: scapular protraction, shoulder adduction and internal rotation, elbow extension, forearm pronation, wrist and finger flexion -Lower extremity synergy patterns -Flexor: hip flexion, abduction, external rotation, knee flexion, ankle dorsiflexion and inversion, toe dorsiflexion -Extensor: hip extension, adduction, internal rotation, knee extension, ankle plantarflexion, inversion, toe plantarflexion -Abnormal gait -Gait pattern distinguished by asymmetry, deviations, and adoption of compensatory strategies -Please see Clinical Review…Stroke: Gait Training ; CINAHL Item Number: T709237 for more information -Sensory system impact -Decreased proprioception contralateral to lesion(4,6) -Contralateral loss of temperature/pain sensation(4,5) -Ipsilateral facial sensory loss(5) -Cognitive system impact -Aphasia -Agnosia(5) -Neglect -Amnesia(5) -Other system impact -Bowel and bladder dysfunction(7) -Dysphagia(5) -Nausea, vertigo(5) -Somnolence(5) -Depression –Presentation, signs and symptoms of unilateral neglect -Hemineglect is most prevalent in the first weeks post stroke and may decrease spontaneously afterwards -Symptoms of neglect vary from patient to patient and may even change over time within a patient -Symptoms associated with neglect can be observed in all sensory modalities (i.e., visual, tactile, auditory, olfactory, and gustatory), but are most commonly visual -Neglect may represent a ‘“gradient” of attentional bias (e.g., from left to right), such that there is a continually increasing probability of detecting stimuli the further to the right of external space these stimuli occur Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

contraindications precautions to test: If a patient has pain, swelling, and/or redness in the calf, or positive Homans’ sign, consult a physician to see if the patient has been screened for DVT

Notify referring physician on positive findings for conditions that may require a special prescription, including the following: –Poststroke shoulder pain that increases with movement; causes may include -adhesive capsulitis -subacromial impingement -rotator cuff pathology -glenohumeral subluxation or acromioclavicular separation –Impaired joint mobility of the elbow (heterotopic ossification), wrist, or hand –Complex regional pain syndrome –Severe cachectic appearance
Avoid pulling on hemiplegic arm during examination

causes: Cerebral thrombosis–Most common cause of stroke–Obstruction or occlusion of a blood vessel, often due to atherosclerotic vascular disease

Cerebral embolism–Second most common cause of stroke–Embolism is commonly due to a cardiac source-History of rheumatic heart disease-Endocarditis-Posttraumatic-Cardiac arrhythmias-Post open-heart  surgery
Cerebral hemorrhage–Third most common cause of stroke (about 13% of strokes)–Chronic hypertension–Cerebral aneurysms–Arteriovenous malformation
pathogenesis: Complete cerebral circulatory arrest results in irreversible cellular damage within minutes(4)
Ischemic strokes cause cerebral edema for 3–4 days after insult(4)–The edema increases intracranial pressure and is the most common cause of death in acute stroke
Impairments result from dysfunction of the area of the brain affected
Different brain areas, including the right parieto-temporal  junction, angular gyrus, right inferior parietal lobe,parahippocampal region, and right superior temporal cortex, have been implicated(27)

Although either right-sided  or left-sided  lesions can produce neglect, it is more common and severe with right hemispherelesions, thought to be due to asymmetrical representations of the body and space in the hemispheres(27)
risk factors for stroke: Nonmodifiable:–Age(1)–Sex: Women have a higher lifetime risk of stroke than men(15)-Men > women at younger age, but higher incidence in women over age 75(1)–Race: more common in Blacks and Hispanics(1,8)–Family history(1)–History of stroke,(1) history of transient ischemic attack (TIA)(5)–Recent myocardial infarction(2,5)

Controllable/Modifiable/Treatable:–Diabetes mellitus(1,2,5,9)–Hypertension(1,2,5,9)–Hypercholesterolemia,(5) hyperlipidemia(2,5,9)–Cardiac disease,(1,2,5,9) congestive heart failure,(5) cardiac arrhythmias,(8) atrial fibrillation,(2,5)valvular heart disease(1)–Carotid stenosis(5)–Obesity(1,2)–Smoking(1,2,5,9)–Use of certain drugs (e.g., sympathomimetics, oral contraceptives, cocaine)(9)–Heavy alcohol consumption(9)–High red blood cell count(8)–Gout(8)–Hypercoagulable states(1,2)

overall contraindications precautions: The presence of unilateral neglect is associated with an increased risk for injury. Safety issues include the following: Increased risk of falls Lack of safety precautions pertaining to the neglected side –Lack of insight into the cause of sustained injuries Collisions with objects or persons causing injury to self or others Unsafe reintegration into community –Unsafe street crossing –Unsafe driving
Notify physician if patient presents with signs and symptoms of a new stroke or a cardiac event

Comorbidities and complications requiring precaution include the following: Osteoporosis DVT Uncontrolled hypertension Seizures –Seizures complicate almost 10% of strokes.(28)Half of seizures occur in the first few days after stroke
Note any comorbidity that may restrict exercise
Use caution during handling, transfers, and positioning to prevent/minimize post-stroke hemiplegic shoulder pain

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -Document type of stroke, location, and size of lesion -What were the symptoms at onset? -How soon after onset did patient receive medical care? -Was patient hospitalized? How long? Any complications during hospital course? -What has the rehabilitation course been to date? -Has there been a recent change in symptoms?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management of patients who have had a stroke varies and depends on cause and severity. Emergency treatment may include thrombolytics within 3 hours of a stroke of thrombotic origin.(2)via mask or nasal cannula to assist in reestablishing circulation and oxygenation; may require intubation if the patient is in a coma Monitoring of blood pressure and cardiac rhythm(1,4) Glycemic control and proper hydration(2,4) Medical control of seizures and infections(4) Above-the-knee  elastic stockings or pneumatic compression devices to help prevent DVT(2) Bed rest initially with head of the bed down in pressure-dependent ischemia and head elevated if aspiration risk(1) NG tube or PEG for patients with dysphagia. All oral intake should be avoided until swallowing is determined to be unimpaired(2) Maintenance of skin and joint integrity with a turning schedule and early physical and occupational therapy(4) Maintenance of bladder function may require catheterization(4) Control of intracranial pressure via antiedemic agents(4) Craniotomy for evacuation of a large intracerebral hematoma or for severe swelling with increased intracranial pressure(8) Carotid endarterectomy to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke(2,4,8) Carotid stenting as an alternative to carotid endarterectomy(8)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? Is the patient medicated for poststroke depression, seizures, pain, or hypercoagulability? Other common prescriptions include medications for hyperlipidemia and hypertensionTo improve perfusion and reduce the risk of returning clots(4) Evidence does not support the routine use of heparin and oral anticoagulants in acute ischemic stroke, due to increased risk of death, symptomatic intracranial hemorrhage, and recurrent strokeGiven within 48 hours of acute ischemic stroke reduces mortality and dependency at 6 months, and increases the likelihood of complete recovery(2,6)Antiplatelet therapy (aspirin, dipyridamole/aspirin, clopidogrel [Plavix], ticlopidine) reduces risk of subsequent ischemic stroke(2)Usually used in patients with cardioembolic stroke or atrial fibrillation(2)long-term,  low-dose  is used to decrease the risk of recurrent ischemic stroke; higher doses may be used in place of anticoagulants and may be recommended for patients with atrial fibrillation(2) ACE inhibitors The risk of recurrent stroke is lowered by a combination of an ACE inhibitor and a thiazide-type  diuretic(2) ACE inhibitors and angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBS) may be used for patients with comorbid diabetes(2) Neuroprotectants(5) Calcium channel antagonists, potassium-channel  openers, glutamate antagonists, antiadhesion molecules, Nmethyl-D-aspartate  (NMDA) receptor antagonists and modulators, alphaamino-3-hydroxy-5-methylisoxazole-4-propionic  acid (AMPA) receptor antagonists, membrane stabilizers, growth factors, and glycine site antagonists Spasticity medication Botulinum toxin type A (Botox) has been shown to improve muscle tone and decrease upper limb spasticity in patients with stroke or traumatic brain injury(39) Intrathecal baclofen is reported to be an effective treatment for post-stroke  spasticity

course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture), what they are used for, and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document any noted aggravating or easing factors
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Patients may describe pain in joints affected by increased tone or joint subluxations
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much). The FLACC scale or the Functional Pain Scale may be used for assessment of pain in nonverbal patients or patients with aphasia. The Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale may be used when rating symptoms caused by exertion such as dyspnea, muscle aches, fatigue, and chest pain
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night related to condition
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician -Unilateral neglect may be confounded by symptoms related to aging, as well as by other symptoms caused by the stroke such as hemiparesis, sensory loss, hypertonicity, and anosognosia -Anosognosia, a lack of insight into impairments, frequently co-occurs  with neglect. Anosognosia of hemiparesis affects ~30% of stroke survivors. Stroke survivors may also have limited insight into their neglect and how neglect affects their ability to perform daily activities (“anosognosia of neglect”)(29) -Approximately one-third  of stroke survivors experience poststroke depression(15)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document any history of respiratory compromise, such as COPD or asthma. Document if the patient is using supplemental oxygen, and how much. Note if patient required a tracheostomy, a ventilator is utilized, or if the patient is receiving respiratory therapy Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ________________________ -Barriers to learning may be severe -Patients with unilateral neglect believe that they have an appropriate representation of their environment, so problems of denial and decreased awareness of the need to compensate for the deficit occur -Rehabilitation of neglect is often hampered by patients’ lack of awareness with regard to their symptoms. Anosodiaphoria (inappropriate lack of concern about impairments) and anosognosia (complete denial of symptoms) are commonly found in association with personal and peripersonal neglect

past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Is the patient employed? What tasks are required at work? Does the patient have household and family responsibilities? Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports or activities? Does the patient drive?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: What is the patient’s reported ADL status? Has the patient received any occupational therapy treatment that included ADL assessment and advice? Document identified ADL limitations -Patients with unilateral neglect may present with unique ADL challenges, such as failing to groom half of the face or failing to eat food on half of their plates. Patients may need to be monitored to ensure that they are eating enough -Document history of equipment use, including self-care  devices, braces and orthoses, ambulatory assistive devices, wheelchairs, wheelchair trays, and arm slings, making note of whether equipment was found to be helpful or satisfactory for its identified purposes
social and occupational history.living environment: Inquire about the layout of the patient’s home lives, caregivers, access to community resources, etc. -Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary? Patient may require grab bars, a shower chair or bench, a shower hose, and/or a commode to assist with bathing and toileting -Are caregivers or family supportive and able to help care for patient? -If patient has already been discharged home, specifically inquire about his/her ability to navigate in the home. Patients with unilateral neglect may report frequent banging into furniture, walls, or door frames -Even mild spatial neglect can be very detrimental to function and independence because so many activities, including working, shopping, and interpersonal interactions, require the ability to perceive and act effortlessly on the immediate environment

relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assistive and adaptive devices –Assess assistive and adaptive devices in use for fit and appropriateness, and assess need for additional devices where indicated –Patient may require a walker, cane, or wheelchair for mobility depending on lower and upper extremity strength, balance, and coordination(7,8) -Use of an ankle foot orthotic (AFO) may be useful if patient presents with footdrop(8) -A knee ankle foot orthotic (KAFO) may be used if the patient demonstrates significant lower extremity weakness or spasticity,(8) but usually an AFO sufficiently controls knee instability(4) -Quad cane, single point cane, hemi-walker,  conventional walker, wheelchair, one-arm  drive wheelchair or power wheelchair may be indicated(8) –Assess the effect of neglect on use of devices, including electrically powered wheelchair, where applicable, using standardized tests and behavioral observation(10) -Arm boards and slings may be used to prevent subluxation(8) and to maintain appropriate position in patients at risk for neglecting arm –Splints and braces to help prevent contractures as indicated(8)
relevant tests and measures.balance: Balance –Patients with unilateral neglect often experience a visual spatial midline shift, resulting in impaired balance –Weight bearing in standing may be asymmetrical due to neglect of the contralesional lower extremity –Berg Balance Assessment, Tinetti Balance Assessment Tool, or Fugl-Meyer Assessment of Physical Performance (FMA) balance subtest(4) may be used to assess balance –Some studies have reported a link between unilateral neglect and pusher syndrome, a behavior pattern in hemiplegic stroke patients that impairs postural balance(4) -Pusher syndrome is characterized by active pushing away from the nonaffected side of the body toward the paretic side, and strong resistance to passive correction of the posture back to vertical -Often associated with postural abnormalities, such as asymmetrical trunk posture toward the paretic side in sitting, standing, and lying, and with perceptual inattention to the paretic side of space or body and an abnormal perception of the body’s midline -Use of the nonaffected arm or leg to actively push toward the paretic side leads to loss of balance and falling toward the paretic sideT709133 for more information Cardiorespiratory function and endurance  (4) –Monitor blood pressure, heart rate, oxygen saturation, and Borg RPE during treatment(4)  –6-minute  walk for distance test (6MWT) may be used to test gait endurance(4)oxygen consumed measured during 6MWT(4)

They may lean toward the ipsilesional side -Unaware their posture isn’t upright even if leaning heavily onto someone or something -Often unaware they are falling –Postural Assessment Scale for Stroke Patients (PASS)(4) may be used to assess posture –Patients who use wheelchairs tend to slump towards the ipsilesional side of their chair and direct their gaze towards ipsilesional space

relevant tests and measures.perception: No single gold-standard  assessment exists(30) –Many assessments measure function impairment by observing ability to perform paper-and-pencil  tasks. Other assessments measure limitations in activity or participation by observing ability to perform ADLs. Virtual-reality computer-based  assessments have more recently been developed(30) –Researchers in the United States found that detection of neglect may depend on the assessment administered(30) -Their data supports the use of functional assessments and virtual-  reality assessments over the use of paper-and-pencil–based  assessments because they were better at detecting neglect –Obtain results of any neuropsychological tests where available -Results of cognitive testing, vision testing, and testing for perceptual deficits including but not limited to neglect (e.g., agnosia) may be available –A large number of simple and rapid tests have been developed for the assessment of neglect. A combination of several tests is usually recommended because of the variability in the tests that patients fail, probably reflecting differences in the nature of the underlying deficits -See section Special tests specific to diagnosis , below, for a list of perception tests that may be used –When a client is medically stable or has a positive screen for the presence of unilateral neglect, an in-depth  evaluation should be done to identify the specific deficits that require intervention –The Catherine Bergego Scale (CBS) is a perception tool that requires direct observation of post-stroke  patients in everyday activities(38) dressing, grooming, eating, mouth cleaning, personal belongings, safe mobility, gaze orientation, auditory attention, spatial orientation, and knowledge of left limbs are evaluated -This scale can also be administered as a questionnaire to assess how the patient self-evaluates  his/her neglect during ADLs using the same scoring system -The CBS captures the heterogeneity of spatial neglect by examining functional performance in personal, peripersonal, and extrapersonal space, as well as performance in perceptual, mental imagery, and motor domains. Thus it is more sensitive than paper-and-pencil  tests(23) –The Kessler Foundation Neglect Assessment Process (KF-NAP)  is an assessment tool based on the CBS(23) -The KF-NAP  provides detailed administration instructions and a scoring chart for the 10 original categories of behavior -The KF-NAP  has been shown to uniquely quantify symptoms of spatial neglect by measuring functional difficulties that are not captured by the FIM or Barthel Index –Tests of neglect might also include asking patients to mime ADL activities, such as combing their hair, shaving, or makingup their face –Inclusion of tests that maintain the complexity of everyday tasks and environments is recommended(31)

prognosis: Unilateral neglect –The rate of recovery from neglect is greatest in the first month poststroke. Recovery can range from a persistent neglect to complete recovery –Patients with neglect have been found to have longer lengths of stay in rehabilitation facilities and lower scores on the FIM, and require more assistance at discharge than patients without neglect –Persistent neglect is associated with poor functional outcome and reduced quality of life(32)

Stroke rehabilitation –Most recovery occurs within 6 months, but the patient may continue to improve functionally with improved sensorimotor reeducation and utilizing adaptive equipment(6) –Cardiac disease is the leading cause of death in the first 5 years after a stroke(1) –Patients who have had a cerebral infarct are at risk for additional strokes and for myocardial infarcts(9)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Clinical guidelines recommend with strong evidence that stroke patients requiring admission to hospital be admitted to a stroke unit with a coordinated multidisciplinary team with a special interest in stroke.(13) Rehabilitation of neglect is often carried out by neuropsychologists, occupational therapists, speech-language  pathologists, physical therapists, optometrists, and orthoptists. Other members of the stroke team may include social workers for equipment and placement issues, nurses for skin care, recreational or vocational therapists, and dietitians. Where applicable, patients may be referred to a disabled drivers’ assessment center for evaluation of fitness to drive
other considerations: Education of healthcare coworkers about unilateral neglect and therapy goals may be necessary(16) –In a qualitative study conducted in Canada, a gap between identified best practices and actual management of poststroke unilateral neglect was investigated –A lack of understanding of therapy goals was identified as one theme. Examples included having to explain to workers on every changing shift that rearrangement of the patient’s room was done deliberately as part of treatment for unilateral neglect and should not be undone

Psychological considerations –A high percentage of stroke survivors experience economic strain, social isolation, decreased community involvement, disruption of family function, poor motivation, dependency, and loss of control(7)
treatment summary: Stroke treatment will vary based on severity, stage of recovery, and therapy setting –Treatment may occur in an acute care hospital, acute rehabilitation hospital/unit, skilled nursing facility, outpatient facility, the home health setting, assisted living center, residential care facility, or transitional living facility(7) –Acute phase(4) -Typically begins within 72 hours of admission -Early mobilization prevents or minimizes effects of deconditioning and secondary impairments, including DVT, pneumonia, and skin breakdown -Encourages movement of hemiparetic side -Patient/family education is important in this phase  –Postacute phase(4) -Patients with moderate to severe impairments may benefit from intensive inpatient rehabilitation -Inpatient rehabilitation within a hospital usually consists of 5–7days/week for 3 hours of therapy per day -Inpatient services in a transitional care unit in an acute care facility or a skilled nursing facility are usually less intense, usually ranging from 1 hour of therapy 2–3 times per week to daily shorter sessions –If further therapy is required after 6 months, this is usually done in an outpatient facility or in the home setting

Unilateral neglect is usually difficult to treat.(10) This may be because it is likely due to different combinations of neuropsychological deficits rather than a disruption of just one cognitive process(10) –One single therapeutic intervention is therefore unlikely to be successful with all individuals with neglect(10) –Clinical guidelines recommend use of interventions that focus on the relevant functional tasks, taking into account the underlying impairment(10) –Evidence from several clinical trials has shown that a variety of interventions are effective at improving occupational performance in patients with unilateral neglect; however, further research is needed to determine whether combining these effective interventions would have an additive effect(18)

Evidence for interventions for neglect is mixed. There is some evidence that cognitive rehabilitation for neglect improves performance on neuropsychological tests, but evidence suggests there is little or no effect of intervention on increasing activity –Cognitive rehabilitation was defined as therapeutic activities designed to decrease the level of cognitive deficits or the resulting disability –Interventions included structured therapy sessions, computerized therapy, prescription of aids, and modification of environment –There is some limited evidence that cognitive rehabilitation may have an immediate beneficial effect on tests of neglect

Treatments targeting spatial representation deficits include(14) –Scanning training –Hemispheric activation approaches -Sensory cueing -Sensory-motor  cueing –CIMT –Mental imagery training –Prism treatment –Eye patching and hemispatial glasses –Caloric stimulation –Optokinetic stimulation – exposure to visual motion –Neck vibration therapy –Trunk rotation therapy

Hemispheric activation approaches –Focus on moving the limb on the side of the neglect –Evidence is conflicting –A potential limitation in this approach is the requirement for patients to actively move the neglected limb, which may not be possible for many of them
CIMT –Is reported to improve arm motor function(7) –However, the use of CIMT is limited to patients who have active control of wrist and hand extension

Authors of a matched-pair  RCT conducted in South Africa indicate that intensive saccadic eye movement training with visual scanning exercises integrated with task-specific  activities improves unilateral spatial neglect(19) –Twenty-four  patients were matched according to their functional level and randomized to either a control group or an experimental group –Both groups received task-specific  activities and the experimental group received saccadic eye movement training with visual scanning exercises in addition –Patients receiving the visual scanning training had significantly improved visual perceptual processing and improved ability to perform ADLs

Researchers of a noncontrolled study conducted in India suggest that task-specific treatment in patients with unilateral neglect can improve functional outcomes and reduce neglect symptoms(20) –Ten patients with unilateral neglect participated in a 6-week  intervention program 5 times weekly that included visual scanning, visual scanning in functional tasks, guiding techniques, and compensatory strategies –Significant improvements in the two outcome measures used, the Catherine Bergego Scale and the FIM, were observed

Authors of an RCT conducted in Germany found no additive effect of hemifield eye patching and optokinetic stimulation to the spontaneous remission of acute spatial neglect after right hemispheric stroke(17) –Twenty-one  patients participated –Outcome measures included a neuropsychological test battery for neglect, as well as impairment and functional tests –Outcomes were measured at baseline, post treatment (day 8), and at 1-month follow-up.  Both groups showed improvements. There were no significant differences between the groups

Mirror therapy –Researchers in Australia investigated the effectiveness of mirror therapy to improve unilateral neglect in a blinded RCT(21) -Forty-eight  patients with unilateral neglect 48 hours after stroke were randomized to mirror therapy or to a control group -During mirror therapy, patients sat at a table in front of a mirror box. The paretic hand was hidden behind the mirror and the unaffected hand was placed in front of the mirror, so that patients could see the unaffected hand in the mirror and not the paretic hand. While patients performed flexion and extension of the unaffected wrist and fingers they were asked to do the same movements with the paretic hand, and they saw the reflection of unaffected hand as being movements of the paretic hand -Training was done 1–2 hours per day 5 days per week -The control group did similar exercises for a similar period of time but with the nonreflective side of the mirror facing the unaffected hand (and the paretic hand out of sight) -Outcome measures included the star cancellation test, the line bisection test, and picture identification task. Secondary measures included the FIM -Improvement was seen in the primary outcome measures in patients who received mirror therapy compared to the control group. Based on the FIM scores, patients in the treatment group were more likely to be independent at 6 months -It was hypothesized that when the nonparetic limb is engaged during motor training, crossed facilitatory drive from the intact hemisphere can cause increased excitability in the homologous motor pathways of the paretic limb

Mental practice –Mental practice uses motor and visual representation without actually executing any physical activity, so it can be used with patients with low motor function. Imagining neglected-side  limb movement is thought to increase the awareness of the neglected side(25) -Researchers in South Korea found that patients with chronic stroke who participated in mental practice showed greater improvement in the line bisection test for neglect as compared to a control group in anRCT involving 30 participants –Combining mental practice with EMG-triggered  electrical stimulation is a novel approach that may be beneficial for reducing neglect(26) -Based on an RCT conducted in South Korea that involved 31participants with unilateral neglect -After the intervention, the experimental group showed a statistically significant improvement in the line bisection test, the star cancellation test, and Catherine Bergego Scale scores

Electrotherapy treatments –Researchers in Japan examined the effect of passive limb activation by functional electrical stimulation (FES) on wheelchair driving for two patients with unilateral spatial neglect(33) -Results differed in the two patients -For one patient, the distance travelled significantly improved after passive limb activation with FES. The authors concluded that passive limb activation appeared to ameliorate the asymmetric spatial representation and reduce the unilateral spatial neglect, especially in the extrapersonal space related to wheelchair driving -Performance did not improve in the other patient –There is moderate-quality  evidence for the effectiveness of noninvasive brain stimulation combined with other therapies on hemispatial neglect and ADL performance after stroke(34) -Based on a 2017 meta-analysis  that included 10 RCTs with a total of 226 participants  -Stimulation included repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) and transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) -Because there is great variability among noninvasive brain stimulation protocols, generalizing resultsis problematic -Treatment effects of the stimulation techniques (tDCS or rTMS) revealed a large effect size for hemispatial neglect and a medium effect size for performance in ADLs –tDCS combined with feedback training (FT) was found to provide a positive effect on unilateral visuospatial neglect in patients who have experienced a subacute stroke(35) -Twelve patients were randomly assigned to either the experimental group (tDCS + FT) or control group (FT only) -The experimental group received 20 minutes of tDCS treatment along with 30 minutes of FT treatment 5 days a week for 3 weeks. The control group received only FT treatment for 30 minutes 5 days a week for 3 weeks -Both groups improved on the Motor-Free  Visual Perception Test (MVPT), line bisection test (LBT), and modified Barthel Index (MBI); however, the experimental group showed significant improvements on these objective measures

Robot-assisted  hand training(22) –Three patients with left-sided  unilateral neglect underwent a 2-week  training program of robotic hand activation in Italy –Patients wore a hand rehabilitation glove that provided computer-controlled repetitive passive mobilization of the fingers –The findings suggest that robot-assisted  hand training might improve visuospatial organization (measured by line crossing test, Bells test, saccadic training test, and sentence reading test), attention (sustained attention to response test), and speed to execute gross movement of the arm, hand, and fingers, as well as fingertip dexterity (Purdue Pegboard test) –Larger-scale  investigations and RCTs are needed .
